elements.content: Nine new compounds, namely, {[Zn­(2-pybim)­(ip)]2·H2O} n (1), [Zn­(2-pybim)2­(Hip)2] n (2), {[Zn­(2-pybim)2­(H2tm)]­(H3tm)} n (3), {[Cd­(2-pybim)­(ip)­(H2O)]2­·H2O} n (4), [Cd­(2-pybim)2­(bz)2] n (5), {[Zn­(3-pybim)2­(Htm)­(H2O)]­·H2O} n (6), [Zn­(4-pybim)2­(pp)1.5] n (7), [Zn2(4-pybim)2­(ip)2] n (8), and [Zn­(4-pybim)­(Htm)­(H2O)] n (9) (H2ip = iso-phthalic acid, H2pp = p-phthalic acid, H3tm = trimesic acid, Hbz = benzoic acid, n-pybim = 2-(n-pyridyl)­benzimidazle [n = 2, 3 4]), were successfully synthesized. Compounds 1, 4, 6, 7, and 9 exhibit one-dimensional chains. Compounds 2, 3, and 5 are zero-dimensional. Stacking interactions extend them into high-dimensional frameworks. Compound 8 can be simplified as a {4.82}­{4.83.102}­{42.6.82.10}­{42.6} topology. The luminescence properties of solid compounds 1–9 were also investigated at 298 K. Remarkably, compound 9 shows excellent luminescence properties with 29.16% quantum yield (QY) and 23.85 (ns) luminescent decay lifetime, which are much higher than the QY and luminescent decay lifetime of the 4-pybim ligand (τ4‑pybim = 1.02 ns, QY4‑pybim = 2.42%) and the other compounds (1–8). On the basis of the results of the comparison of the crystal structures and luminescence properties of compounds 1–9, our conclusions indicate that a crystal structure with parallel-dispaced molecular packing (J-aggregation) interactions of strong π-electron conjugate systems can achieve a high luminescence efficiency.

Remarkably, compound 9 shows excellent luminescence properties with 29.16% quantum yield (QY) and 23.85 (ns) luminescent decay lifetime, which are much higher than the QY and luminescent decay lifetime of the 4-pybim ligand (τ4-pybim = 1.02 ns, QY4-pybim = 2.42%) and the other compounds (1-8). elements.content: In this work, nine new Zn/Cd­(II)-organic architectures based on rigid n-pybim (n = 2, 3, 4) and aromatic carboxylic acids were synthesized. The solid compound 9 shows excellent luminescence properties with 29.16% quantum yield and 23.85 (ns) luminescent lifetime at 298 K.
elements.clean_text: In this work, nine new Zn/Cd(II)-organic architectures based on rigid n-pybim (n = 2, 3, 4) and aromatic carboxylic acids were synthesized. The solid compound 9 shows excellent luminescence properties with 29.16% quantum yield and 23.85 (ns) luminescent lifetime at 298 K.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Fluorescent materials have been widely recognized because of their widespread applications in lighting, chemical sensing, and optics. Fluorescent materials can be easily classified into inorganic and organic fluorescent materials. Some inorganic fluorescent materials have been commercialized and can be used as fluorescent lamps. Their distinct luminescent properties are derived from narrow emission peaks of lanthanide metal ions and a high color purity. In addition to inorganic fluorescent materials, organic fluorescent materials have been widely explored. Since the advent of organic light-emitting diodes, more and more organic luminescence materials have been developed. However, the synthesis of inorganic fluorescent materials mainly involves a high-temperature solid-phase method, which is carried out under conditions of up to several thousands of degrees in the Celsius scale and has extremely high requirements on equipment. The synthesis of organic fluorescent materials is usually complicated, and many synthesis steps and purifications are difficult. As a novel functional luminescent material, luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) have received more and more attention. In comparison with the inorganic and organic fluorescent materials, LMOFs involve simple synthesis and mild reaction conditions, mainly under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. LMOFs can produce fluorescence through many ways, such as the organic ligand moiety and inorganic metal moiety in structures and a charge transfer between a metal and a ligand. MOF luminescence can also be induced by encapsulating a guest molecule with fluorescent properties. Different fluorescent properties can be produced by selecting different luminescent elements. LMOFs have many advantages over traditional inorganic or organic fluorescent materials. The problem with these scintillating MOFs is that the high quantum yields (QYs) of LMOF materials are almost based on expensive lanthanide metals and rare earth metals. At present, the QYs of low-cost Zn/Cd­(II)–organic architectures are low, rarely exceeding 20%. How to choose accurate ligands to assemble new Zn/Cd­(II)–organic architectures is the key point to improve QYs of Zn/Cd­(II)–organic architectures.

Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Fluorescent materials have been widely recognized because of their widespread applications in lighting, chemical sensing, and optics. Fluorescent materials can be easily classified into inorganic and organic fluorescent materials. Some inorganic fluorescent materials have been commercialized and can be used as fluorescent lamps. Their distinct luminescent properties are derived from narrow emission peaks of lanthanide metal ions and a high color purity. In addition to inorganic fluorescent materials, organic fluorescent materials have been widely explored. Since the advent of organic light-emitting diodes, more and more organic luminescence materials have been developed. However, the synthesis of inorganic fluorescent materials mainly involves a high-temperature solid-phase method, which is carried out under conditions of up to several thousands of degrees in the Celsius scale and has extremely high requirements on equipment. The synthesis of organic fluorescent materials is usually complicated, and many synthesis steps and purifications are difficult. As a novel functional luminescent material, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have received more and more attention. In comparison with the inorganic and organic fluorescent materials, LMOFs involve simple synthesis and mild reaction conditions, mainly under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. LMOFs can produce fluorescence through many ways, such as the organic ligand moiety and inorganic metal moiety in structures and a charge transfer between a metal and a ligand. MOF luminescence can also be induced by encapsulating a guest molecule with fluorescent properties. Different fluorescent properties can be produced by selecting different luminescent elements. LMOFs have many advantages over traditional inorganic or organic fluorescent materials. The problem with these scintillating MOFs is that the high quantum yields (QYs) of LMOF materials are almost based on expensive lanthanide metals and rare earth metals. At present, the QYs of low-cost Zn/Cd(II)-organic architectures are low, rarely exceeding 20%. How to choose accurate ligands to assemble new Zn/Cd(II)-organic architectures is the key point to improve QYs of Zn/Cd(II)-organic architectures.

elements.content: There are two kinds of ligands we were attracted to study. First, benzimidazole-containing ligands have a special type of aromatic heterocyclic ring containing two nitrogen atoms. NH in the ring can form a conventional hydrogen bond as a proton donor, and the wide range of electron conjugation systems within the rings can cause a π–π interaction. Mutual interactions can be recognized between molecules, making it possible to form a new supramolecular compound via self-assembly. Second, benzimidazole-based complexes have unique fluorescent properties and good magnetic properties, catalysis, and biological activity. Third, simple rigid aromatic carboxylic acids, such as H2ip acid, H2pp acid, H3tm acid, and Hbz acid, have been studied because they exhibit flexible coordination modes and can be fully or partially deprotonated. They can serve as a donor/acceptor of hydrogen bonds, contributing to the high-dimensional framework. The skeleton of the complex can be further stabilized by aromatic carboxylic acid ligands because of the stacking interactions of benzene rings. Luminescent properties of coordination polymers are considerably affected for the coordinations of metals and ligands. Therefore, highly efficient luminescent materials can be obtained by adjusting metal centers, organic ligands, and synthesis conditions. Zn-MOFs and Cd-MOFs can exhibit certain fluorescence properties when Zn and Cd are coordinated to their own fluorescent organic ligands; furthermore, various good candidates of luminescent coordination polymers are built from π-electron-rich conjugated organic linkers with Zn2+ or Cd2+.

First, benzimidazole-containing ligands have a special type of aromatic heterocyclic ring containing two nitrogen atoms. NH in the ring can form a conventional hydrogen bond as a proton donor, and the wide range of electron conjugation systems within the rings can cause a π-π interaction. Mutual interactions can be recognized between molecules, making it possible to form a new supramolecular compound via self-assembly. Second, benzimidazole-based complexes have unique fluorescent properties and good magnetic properties, catalysis, and biological activity. Third, simple rigid aromatic carboxylic acids, such as H2ip acid, H2pp acid, H3tm acid, and Hbz acid, have been studied because they exhibit flexible coordination modes and can be fully or partially deprotonated. They can serve as a donor/acceptor of hydrogen bonds, contributing to the high-dimensional framework. The skeleton of the complex can be further stabilized by aromatic carboxylic acid ligands because of the stacking interactions of benzene rings. Luminescent properties of coordination polymers are considerably affected for the coordinations of metals and ligands. Therefore, highly efficient luminescent materials can be obtained by adjusting metal centers, organic ligands, and synthesis conditions. Zn-MOFs and Cd-MOFs can exhibit certain fluorescence properties when Zn and Cd are coordinated to their own fluorescent organic ligands; furthermore, various good candidates of luminescent coordination polymers are built from π-electron-rich conjugated organic linkers with Zn2+ or Cd2+.

elements.content: On the basis of these considerations, we chose n-pybim (n = 2, 3, 4; ) in combination with an aromatic carboxylic acid () as a ligand because of their relatively simple coordination mode and rich π-conjugated system. We successfully synthesized nine new compounds, namely, {[Zn­(2-pybim)­(ip)]2­·H2O} n (1), [Zn­(2-pybim)2­(Hip)2] n (2), {[Zn­(2-pybim)2­(H2tm)]­(H3tm)} n (3), {[Cd­(2-pybim)­(ip)­(H2O)]2­·H2O} n (4), [Cd­(2-pybim)2­(bz)2] n (5), {[Zn­(3-pybim)2­(Htm)­(H2O)]­·H2O} n (6), [Zn­(4-pybim)2­(pp)1.5] n (7), [Zn2(4-pybim)­(ip)2] n (8), and [Zn­(4-pybim)­(Htm)­(H2O)] n (9). Compounds 1, 4, 6, 7, and 9 show one-dimensional (1D) chains. Compounds 2, 3, and 5 are zero-dimensional (0D). Mutual inductions between molecules extend them into high-dimensional frameworks. We tested the fluorescence properties of the solid compounds and free ligands at 298 K. Notably, the QY (29.16%) and luminescent lifetime (τ = 23.85 ns) of compound 9 are much higher than those of compounds based on n-pybim. The relevant crystallographic parameters are summarized in , and the selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1.

All of the compounds were obtained under similar hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1–3 and 6–9 were prepared under hydrothermal conditions by adding sodium carbonate to water and then heating to 160 °C for 4 days. Compounds 4 and 5 were synthesized by adding DMF and triethylamine in water and then heating to 90 °C for 3 days. The synthesis of compound 1 is described herein, and the syntheses of compounds 2–9 are provided in Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses of Compounds 1-9 

All of the compounds were obtained under similar hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1-3 and 6-9 were prepared under hydrothermal conditions by adding sodium carbonate to water and then heating to 160 °C for 4 days. Compounds 4 and 5 were synthesized by adding DMF and triethylamine in water and then heating to 90 °C for 3 days. The synthesis of compound 1 is described herein, and the syntheses of compounds 2-9 are provided in Supporting Information.

elements.content: 0.2 mmol of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 2-pybim, H2ip acid, Na2CO3, and 15 mL of water were added to a Teflon tube. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred with a glass rod for about 5 min, reacted in a 160 °C oven for 4 days, and then cooled at ambient temperature. The yield of colorless crystals of compound 1 was 53%. Elemental analyses are displayed in Table S2.

{[Zn(2-pybim)(ip)] n ⋅H2O} n  (1)

0.2 mmol of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O, 2-pybim, H2ip acid, Na2CO3, and 15 mL of water were added to a Teflon tube. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred with a glass rod for about 5 min, reacted in a 160 °C oven for 4 days, and then cooled at ambient temperature. The yield of colorless crystals of compound 1 was 53%. Elemental analyses are displayed in Table S2.

elements.content: A series of new Zn or Cd compounds were successfully synthesized by carefully selecting rigid aromatic carboxylic acids and benzimidazole derivatives. Compounds 1–5, 6, and 7–9 were based on 2-, 3-, and 4-pybim ligands, respectively. DMF, triethylamine, or Na2CO3 were added to raise the pH of the mixtures. However, we failed to obtain compounds 1–9 without DMF, triethylamine, or Na2CO3, implying the important role of alkaline on the crystallization of compounds 1–9.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Infrared Spectra of Compounds 1-9 

A series of new Zn or Cd compounds were successfully synthesized by carefully selecting rigid aromatic carboxylic acids and benzimidazole derivatives. Compounds 1-5, 6, and 7-9 were based on 2-, 3-, and 4-pybim ligands, respectively. DMF, triethylamine, or Na2CO3 were added to raise the pH of the mixtures. However, we failed to obtain compounds 1-9 without DMF, triethylamine, or Na2CO3, implying the important role of alkaline on the crystallization of compounds 1-9.

elements.content: The representative characteristic absorption peaks of 1–9 are summarized in (Figure S1). The symmetric υs­(COO–) and antisymmetric υas­(−COO–) stretching of the carboxylate vibration characteristic peaks indicate that carboxyl oxygen in the ligands participates in the coordination. The characteristic stretching vibration absorption peaks υ­(CN) in n-pybim suggest that nitrogen atoms participate in the coordination.

The characteristic stretching vibration absorption peaks υ(CN) in n-pybim suggest that nitrogen atoms participate in the coordination.

Compound 1 displays a 1D ladder chain. Two Zn­(II) centers, two 2-pybim, two ip2– anions, and one free H2O are in the unit of 1 (a). Six-coordinated Zn1 is completed by four O atoms (O3, O4, O5, and O6) from two ip2– and two N atoms (N4 and N6) from one 2-pybim. Five-coordinated Zn2 is completed by three O atoms (O1, O7A, and O2B) from three ip2– and two N atoms (N2 and N3) from one 2-pybim to form a distorted trigonal bipyramid configuration. The ip2– anions in compound 1 have two coordination modes. One carboxylic group of the ip2– anion bridged Zn1 and Zn2 through the μ2-kη n :η 1 :η 1 :η 0 mode, whereas the other carboxylic group linked three Zn centers through the μ3-kη 1 :η 1 :η 1 :η 1 mode (b and Figure S2). Four ip2– anions and four Zn­(II) centers form a ring with distances from the diagonal Zn atoms of 13.8017 and 13.1881 Å. n-pybim not only contains an imidazole nitrogen atom to be used as a donor but also comprises aromatic rings to form π–π interactions. There are π–π interactions between 2-pybims from adjacent chains (c). Two intermolecular hydrogen bonds (N1–H1···O8, C15–H15···O8) also exist. In these bonds, the acceptor oxygen atom is derived from the same uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom, whereas the donors are from two different atoms. Therefore, the 1D chains are connected via the weak π–π interactions of 2-pybim and hydrogen bonds, further forming a three-dimensional (3D) framework (d).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Structure of {[Zn(2-pybim)(ip)]2⋅H2O} n  (1)

Compound 1 displays a 1D ladder chain. Two Zn(II) centers, two 2-pybim, two ip2- anions, and one free H2O are in the unit of 1 (a). Six-coordinated Zn1 is completed by four O atoms (O3, O4, O5, and O6) from two ip2- and two N atoms (N4 and N6) from one 2-pybim. Five-coordinated Zn2 is completed by three O atoms (O1, O7A, and O2B) from three ip2- and two N atoms (N2 and N3) from one 2-pybim to form a distorted trigonal bipyramid configuration. The ip2- anions in compound 1 have two coordination modes. One carboxylic group of the ip2- anion bridged Zn1 and Zn2 through the μ2-kη  n  :η 1 :η 1 :η 0 mode, whereas the other carboxylic group linked three Zn centers through the μ3-kη 1 :η 1 :η 1 :η 1 mode (b and Figure S2). Four ip2- anions and four Zn(II) centers form a ring with distances from the diagonal Zn atoms of 13.8017 and 13.1881 Å. n-pybim not only contains an imidazole nitrogen atom to be used as a donor but also comprises aromatic rings to form π-π interactions. There are π-π interactions between 2-pybims from adjacent chains (c). Two intermolecular hydrogen bonds (N1-H1⋅⋅⋅O8, C15-H15⋅⋅⋅O8) also exist. In these bonds, the acceptor oxygen atom is derived from the same uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom, whereas the donors are from two different atoms. Therefore, the 1D chains are connected via the weak π-π interactions of 2-pybim and hydrogen bonds, further forming a three-dimensional (3D) framework (d).

elements.content: Compound 4 displays a zigzag 1D chain (b). Two Cd­(II) centers, two ip2– linkers, two 2-pybim, and three H2O molecules (one free and two coordinated) in the unit of 4 (a). Interestingly, two Cd centers display two different coordination geometries. A seven-coordinate Cd1 center forms a pentagonal bipyramid coordination with [CdN2O5], whereas a six-coordinate Cd2 center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination with [CdN2O4]. The two completely deprotonated ip2– linkers adopt different coordinated modes (c). In mode a, one carboxyl group of the ip2– anion adopts a μ1 -η 1: η0 mode to coordinate with one Cd­(II) cation, and the other carboxyl group coordinates with Cd­(II) in a chelation mode. In contrast to mode a, mode b involves the use of the chelation mode by both carboxyl groups of the ip2– anion. The 2-pybim ligands are suspended on both sides of the chain in a chelating coupled mode. So 1D chains are connected via hydrogen bonds (C16–H16···O2W) and π–π interactions, further forming a 3D interpenetrating structure (d and Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[Cd(2-pybim)(ip)(H2O)]2⋅H2O} n  (4)

Compound 4 displays a zigzag 1D chain (b). Two Cd(II) centers, two ip2- linkers, two 2-pybim, and three H2O molecules (one free and two coordinated) in the unit of 4 (a). Interestingly, two Cd centers display two different coordination geometries. A seven-coordinate Cd1 center forms a pentagonal bipyramid coordination with [CdN2O5], whereas a six-coordinate Cd2 center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination with [CdN2O4]. The two completely deprotonated ip2- linkers adopt different coordinated modes (c). In mode a, one carboxyl group of the ip2- anion adopts a μ1 -η 1: η0 mode to coordinate with one Cd(II) cation, and the other carboxyl group coordinates with Cd(II) in a chelation mode. In contrast to mode a, mode b involves the use of the chelation mode by both carboxyl groups of the ip2- anion. The 2-pybim ligands are suspended on both sides of the chain in a chelating coupled mode. So 1D chains are connected via hydrogen bonds (C16-H16⋅⋅⋅O2W) and π-π interactions, further forming a 3D interpenetrating structure (d and Figure S3).

elements.content: There are one unique Zn­(II) center, two neutral 2-pybim, and two incompletely deprotonated Hip– anions in the unit of 2 (a). Compound 3 includes one Zn­(II) center, two neutral 2-pybim, only one removed proton H2tm– anion, and one free H3tm molecule (a). Compound 5 includes one Cd­(II) ion, two neutral 2-pybim, and two bz– anions (a). Here, in compounds 2, 3, and 5, the hexa-coordinate M­(II) ion is completed with four N from two chelated 2-pybim and two carboxylate O. These compounds displayed distorted octahedral structures. Compounds 2, 3, and 5 revealing 0D are uncommonly ascribed to only one deprotonated carboxylate group coordinated to the M­(II) cation. Many mutual inductions are found because of the incompletely deprotonated aromatic carboxylic acid ligands and 2-pybim ligand. In compound 2, 2-pybim and Hip– of adjacent units are linked by two intermolecular hydrogen bonds: N3–H3···O4 and O3–H3B···O3, which connect asymmetric units of 2 into a 1D chain (b). The distance of C–H···π is about 3.655 Å, thereby packing 1D chains into a 2D layer (c). Numerous hydrogen bonds (O3–H3···O10, O5–H5···O8, O7–H7···O6, C12–H12···O4, and C37–H37···O3) are found in compound 3. These weak bonds help compound 3 become a 1D hydrogen bond chain (b). With the aid of hydrogen bonds (N2–H2···O10), in which N atoms from 2-pybim serve as donors and O atoms from free H3tm molecule serve as acceptors, the 1D chains are further connected into a 2D layer (c). The 2D layers are packed into a 3D network through π–π interactions (d). In compound 5, three kinds of weak interactions, such as C–H···π between adjacent 2-pybim molecules, hydrogen bonds, and π aggregations, help units of 5 become a 1D chain (b).

elements.content: One pyridyl N atom, one water O atom, and two N offered by two different Htm2– anions surround the Zn­(II) center, forming a tetrahedral geometry. The incompletely deprotonated Htm2– anions bridge Zn­(II) ions to form a 1D chain with 3-pybim ligands alongside the crystallographic a axis (a,b). The hydrogen bonds of O2W–H2WA···O3­(Htm2–)/2.915/166° and O2W–H2WB···O6­(Htm2–)/2.771 Å/176° are present between free H2O molecules and O atoms from neighboring chains. Free H2O molecules are combined with the adjacent chain. Two reversed chains are connected into a 1D ladder-like double chain through the hydrogen bonds of C14–H14···N2­(miz)/3.300 Å/138°, N2–H2···O5­(Htm2–)/ 2.961 Å/159° and weak π stacking interactions between Htm2– anions (Figure S4). As shown in c, the distance of 3.62 Å of neighboring benzimidazole rings indicates a weak π–π interaction, which packs 1D chains into a 2D layer (c). The formation of 3D structures is ultimately attributed to hydrogen bonds (O4–H4···N1/2.587 Å/166°) between H3tm ligands and 3-pybim (d).

elements.content: Compound 7 features a 1D chain (b). A six-coordinate Zn­(II) center is completed by O1, O2, O3, and O4A from three pp2– anions and N1 and N4 from two 4-pybim ligands (a). Interestingly, the carboxylate groups of two independent pp2– ligands adopt monodentate-bridging and bidentate chelating modes to form [Zn2(COO)4] secondary units. As shown in c, two intermolecular hydrogen bonds are present. (a) N3–H3···O5 exists in the nitrogen atoms of the pyridine ring from 4-pybim and the oxygen atoms of pp2–. (b) C16–H16···O2 are present in the C of 4-pybim and O of pp2–. Except for these hydrogen bonds, two different weak π–π interactions are observed, and they are reversed face to face with imidazole and phenyl groups between adjacent benzimidazole from antiparallel chains. The distances between planes C7–C8–C9–C10–C11–C12 and C6–N2–C7–C8–N3 are about 3.72 and 3.76 Å. Mutual inductions extend 1D chains to a 3D network finally.

elements.content: There are two Zn­(II) centers, two ip2– anions, and one neutral 4-pybim ligand in 8 (a). The Zn1 center displays a [ZnO3N] environment. And the Zn2 center displays a [ZnO4N] geometry. As shown in b,c, two modes of carboxylate oxygen atoms in complex 8 are present. In mode a, only one O atom of one carboxyl group is coordinated with metal ion, and the other carboxyl group chelate metal ion. In mode b, the four O atoms of the ip2– anions link the zinc­(II) ion with a bridging mode, and each ip2– anion connects four Zn (II) ions. Interestingly, in compound 8, 4-pybim and ip2– anions bridge different Zn­(II) ions as a linker, which helps compound 8 result in a 3D framework (d). 4-Pybim of compound 8 adopts a strongly twisted molecular structure. Pyridine, imidazole, and benzene rings are not in one plane with dihedral angles 34.225° (pyridine ring and the imidazole ring) and 35.221° (pyridine ring and the benzene ring).

elements.content: Compound 9 features a 1D sinusoidal chain and crystallizes P21 /c (b). There are one Zn­(II) center, one 4-pybim, one Htm2–, and one water in 9 (a). In this structure, the carboxyl groups of Htm2– anions bridge Zn (II) ions, and the distance of adjacent Zn···Zn is 7.8384 Å (Figures S5). In addition, the 4-pybim’s multiple rings are almost in one plane because the dihedral angle between the pyridine plane and the imidazole plane is about 5.658°, the dihedral angle between the pyridine plane and the benzene plane is about 5.226°, and the dihedral angle between the imidazole plane and the benzene plane is about 1.022°, respectively (c). The opposite parallel-displaced 4-pybim can generate three strong J-aggregations (3.68, 341, and 3.56 Å). 4-Pybim easily generates hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions with adjacent chains because 4-pybim coordinates Zn­(II) with a terminal pyridine N atom and is located on both sides of the 1D chain like a wing. Here, five hydrogen bonds, namely, N2–H2···O2 (2.854 Å, 163°), C18–H18···O5 (3.176 Å, 130°), O1W–H1WB···O2 (2.919 Å, 149°), O3–H3···O4 (2.704 Å, 166°), and C3–H3···O4 (2.704 Å, 166°), are present (d). Mutual inductions pack 1D chains into a 3D framework finally (e).

elements.content: n-Pybim (n = 2, 3, 4), a series of carboxylic acids, and Zn­(II) or Cd­(II) are used to synthesize nine coordination polymers. All of these compounds show different kinds of coordination structures. The comparison of compounds 1–9 show that the pyridyl nitrogen positions of n-pybim play an important role in featuring compounds. Compounds 1–5 are synthesized with the same 2-pybim ligands but with different auxiliary ligands. Among these compounds, 2-pybim acts as a chelating ligand. In compounds 1 and 2, Zn­(II) metal centers connect 2-pybim and H2ip. Complex 1 is a 1D ladder chain, whereas complex 2 is a 0D structure. When Cd­(II) is used, compound 4 displays a 1D zigzag chain structure. Although compounds 3 and 5 are linked by different auxiliary ligands, they simultaneously coordinate two 2-pybim ligands, thereby exhibiting a 0D structure. Only compound 6 is synthesized with 3-pybim, which employs an end-on fashion. In compounds 7 and 9, 4-pybim uses the end-on fashion by a terminal pyridine nitrogen atom, but they exhibit different 1D networks. It is because they have different auxiliary ligands. For compound 8, 4-pybim participates in coordination with the end-to-end bridging mode. With the help of ip2–, complex 8 displays a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Different Ligands

 n-Pybim (n = 2, 3, 4), a series of carboxylic acids, and Zn(II) or Cd(II) are used to synthesize nine coordination polymers. All of these compounds show different kinds of coordination structures. The comparison of compounds 1-9 show that the pyridyl nitrogen positions of n-pybim play an important role in featuring compounds. Compounds 1-5 are synthesized with the same 2-pybim ligands but with different auxiliary ligands. Among these compounds, 2-pybim acts as a chelating ligand. In compounds 1 and 2, Zn(II) metal centers connect 2-pybim and H2ip. Complex 1 is a 1D ladder chain, whereas complex 2 is a 0D structure. When Cd(II) is used, compound 4 displays a 1D zigzag chain structure. Although compounds 3 and 5 are linked by different auxiliary ligands, they simultaneously coordinate two 2-pybim ligands, thereby exhibiting a 0D structure. Only compound 6 is synthesized with 3-pybim, which employs an end-on fashion. In compounds 7 and 9, 4-pybim uses the end-on fashion by a terminal pyridine nitrogen atom, but they exhibit different 1D networks. It is because they have different auxiliary ligands. For compound 8, 4-pybim participates in coordination with the end-to-end bridging mode. With the help of ip2-, complex 8 displays a 3D framework.

elements.content: Numerous oxygen and nitrogen atoms are present in ligands. The stability and molecular recognition ability of polymers should be improved. Poly­(carboxylic acid) ligands can serve as donors or acceptors of hydrogen bonds because they can be deprotonated in whole or in part. Nitrogen atoms can also act as a donor to facilitate the formation of hydrogen bonds. These contribute to the high-dimensional structures.

elements.content: n-Pybim is designed and synthesized as the first ligand, and the aromatic carboxylic acid is selected as the second ligand. These ligands show the following characteristics. (1) A π-electron-rich conjugated benzene ring system not only affects the coordination mode of ligands but also likely forms π–π stacking interactions. (2) The extended π-conjugated system is beneficial for forming the final supramolecular lattices. Thus, these compounds are also constructed into high-dimensional networks. The comparison of compounds 1–5 based on 2-pybim ligand also shows that the adjacent 2-pybim ligands in compound 1 have a small π overlap. For compound 2, the aromatic rings among 2-pybim ligands hardly display π-stacking because the distance of the adjacent 2-pybim is large. Instead, the aromatic rings of Hip– anions have C–H···π interactions. In compound 3, only the terminal pyridine ring and the benzene ring form π-overlap because the distance of antiparallel 2-pybim misalignments is relatively large. In compound 4, the adjacent 1D chains form a 2D interpenetrating structure by relatively weak π–π interactions. For compound 5, C–H···π overlap is formed from the pyridine carbon atoms to benzene rings of reversed adjacent 2-pybim ligands. However, π-electron conjugate systems are present to imidazoles from another pair of adjacent 2-pybim ligands. For compound 6, π–π interactions are formed because the distance of benzimidazole of 3-pybim is about 3.62 Å, and the 1D structures are extended into a 3D structure. For compound 7, there are π-electron conjugate systems for the benzimidazole of 4-pybim with distances of 3.72 and 3.62 Å, which also help compound 7 extend a 2D layer. 4-Pybim of compound 8 adopts a strongly twisted molecular structure. Pyridine, imidazole, and benzene rings are not in one plane with dihedral angles 34.225° and 35.221°. Interestingly, in compound 9, 4-pybim forms strong π-electron conjugate systems for the distances of parallel-displaced 4-pybim are 3.68, 3.41, and 3.56 Å, which help the expand 1D structures into a much stabler 3D structure. Therefore, the type of ligand has important scientific relevance and practical value in designing and synthesizing complexes with novel structures and special properties.

elements.content:
Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted at 25–800 °C with N2 to estimate the stability of compounds 1 – 9. The results for compounds 1 – 9 are shown in Table S4 (Figure S6).

The comparison of the experimental and simulated XRD spectra of compounds 1 – 9 (Figure S7) shows that the positions of the diffraction peaks are consistent, indicating that compounds 1 – 9 are pure phases and do not contain impurities. The difference in the intensity of the curves is attributed to the preferred orientation of the crystals in operation.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and PXRD Results

Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted at 25-800 °C with N2 to estimate the stability of compounds 1 - 9. The results for compounds 1  -  9 are shown in Table S4 (Figure S6).

The comparison of the experimental and simulated XRD spectra of compounds 1 - 9 (Figure S7) shows that the positions of the diffraction peaks are consistent, indicating that compounds 1 - 9 are pure phases and do not contain impurities. The difference in the intensity of the curves is attributed to the preferred orientation of the crystals in operation.

elements.content: Benzimidazole and their derivatives are common nitrogen heterocyclic ligands that contain π–π* charge transitions. Therefore, the coordination of nitrogen heterocyclic ligands with d10 metal also has a certain fluorescent property. At room temperature, the solid fluorescence properties of the organic ligands and compounds 1–9 are tested (). The aromatic carboxylic acids included conjugated benzene rings, and n-pybim ligands contain pyridine and benzimidazole rings. Thus, the emission spectra of these organic ligands are attributed to the π–π* transition in the organic molecule. The emission spectra of compounds 1–9 may stem from the intraligand charge transfer and LLCT mixtures. They are inherently neither MLCT nor LMCT because Zn­(II)/Cd­(II) ions are not easily oxidized or reduced. The difference in fluorescence between compounds 1–9 is ascribed to the electronic properties of different the metal centers as well as the different luminescence phenomena caused by different coordination modes, thereby affecting the stability of the structures and causing the compounds’ fluorescence to shift to different degrees.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Benzimidazole and their derivatives are common nitrogen heterocyclic ligands that contain π-π* charge transitions. Therefore, the coordination of nitrogen heterocyclic ligands with d10 metal also has a certain fluorescent property. At room temperature, the solid fluorescence properties of the organic ligands and compounds 1-9 are tested (). The aromatic carboxylic acids included conjugated benzene rings, and n-pybim ligands contain pyridine and benzimidazole rings. Thus, the emission spectra of these organic ligands are attributed to the π-π* transition in the organic molecule. The emission spectra of compounds 1-9 may stem from the intraligand charge transfer and LLCT mixtures. They are inherently neither MLCT nor LMCT because Zn(II)/Cd(II) ions are not easily oxidized or reduced. The difference in fluorescence between compounds 1-9 is ascribed to the electronic properties of different the metal centers as well as the different luminescence phenomena caused by different coordination modes, thereby affecting the stability of the structures and causing the compounds' fluorescence to shift to different degrees.

elements.content: The QYs and fluorescence lifetimes of n-pybim and compounds 1–9 were examined to further investigate the fluorescence properties of the compounds. The QY depends on radiative and nonradiative transition processes, that is, the relative rates of fluorescence emission, intersystem crossing, external transfer, and internal transfer. An exponential function as I(t) = A exp­(−t/τ) is used to calculate the luminescence lifetime. In the singlet excited state, two electrons are spin-parallel, singlet molecules have diamagnetic properties, and the average lifetime of their excited states is approximately 10–6–10–9 s. The triplet molecules have paramagnetic properties, and the average lifetime of the excited states is >10–4–1 s. The QYs and decay lifetimes of free n-pybim ligands and compounds 1–9 are shown in ( and S8). The QY values of compounds 3, 5, and 7 are much lower (QY3 = 1.38%, QY5 = 1.88%, and QY7 = 1.79%) than those of n-pybim. However, the QY values of compounds 8 and 9 (QY8 = 15.48% and QY9 = 29.16%) based on 4-pybim are higher than those of free 4-pybim (QY4‑pybim = 2.42). The high QY of compound 8 is mainly due to the strong coordination of the rigid 4-pybim and ip2– with the metal Zn (II) center, forming a fixed 3D MOF structure, thereby reducing the fluorescence quenching caused by ligand stacking and preventing torsional relaxation. Obviously, 4-pybim of compound 8 displays a strongly twisted molecular structure. The use of a distorted molecular luminescent structure in the compound is similar to dispersing luminescent molecules in the parent material, attenuating exciton (dipole) interactions between adjacent molecules. Increasing the intermolecular distance can effectively improve the solid-state luminous efficiency and lose the charge transfer between molecules (the emission lifetimes of compound 8 is only 2.90 ns). This strategy is not the most ideal method. Therefore, only changing the intermolecular packing mode without increasing the intermolecular distance is a good method for solid-state luminescence efficiency. The synergistic effect between hydrogen bonds and π–π interaction is used to stabilize the close-range and coplanar stacking of π-conjugated molecules. The pyridine ring, imidazole ring, and benzene ring of the ligand 4-pybim of compound 9 are almost in the same plane. In the case of misaligned parallel 4-pybim stacks, a strong π–π interaction exists. Strong J-aggregation action indicates the strong coupling of intermolecular π orbitals, which facilitate the transfer of carriers between molecules. The uniformity of high luminescence efficiency and high carrier mobility can be achieved, thereby effectively improving the QY and emission lifetimes of compound 9 (29.16% and 23.85 ns). This result is of great importance for the preparation of high-performance electroluminescent devices, especially for electric pump lasers. As shown in and S8, the emissions of compounds 1–9 result from a singlet state and not from a triplet state because the luminescence lifetimes of complexes 1–9 are in the range of 10–6–10–9 s.

The high QY of compound 8 is mainly due to the strong coordination of the rigid 4-pybim and ip2- with the metal Zn (II) center, forming a fixed 3D MOF structure, thereby reducing the fluorescence quenching caused by ligand stacking and preventing torsional relaxation. Obviously, 4-pybim of compound 8 displays a strongly twisted molecular structure. The use of a distorted molecular luminescent structure in the compound is similar to dispersing luminescent molecules in the parent material, attenuating exciton (dipole) interactions between adjacent molecules. Increasing the intermolecular distance can effectively improve the solid-state luminous efficiency and lose the charge transfer between molecules (the emission lifetimes of compound 8 is only 2.90 ns). This strategy is not the most ideal method. Therefore, only changing the intermolecular packing mode without increasing the intermolecular distance is a good method for solid-state luminescence efficiency. The synergistic effect between hydrogen bonds and π-π interaction is used to stabilize the close-range and coplanar stacking of π-conjugated molecules. The pyridine ring, imidazole ring, and benzene ring of the ligand 4-pybim of compound 9 are almost in the same plane. In the case of misaligned parallel 4-pybim stacks, a strong π-π interaction exists. Strong J-aggregation action indicates the strong coupling of intermolecular π orbitals, which facilitate the transfer of carriers between molecules. The uniformity of high luminescence efficiency and high carrier mobility can be achieved, thereby effectively improving the QY and emission lifetimes of compound 9 (29.16% and 23.85 ns). This result is of great importance for the preparation of high-performance electroluminescent devices, especially for electric pump lasers. As shown in  and S8, the emissions of compounds 1-9 result from a singlet state and not from a triplet state because the luminescence lifetimes of complexes 1-9 are in the range of 10-6-10-9 s.

Our analysis reveals that using a twisted luminescent molecular structure to increase the distance between molecules can effectively improve the QYs of compounds. The dipole stacking method of misaligned parallel molecules (J-aggregate) can improve the QY and increase the fluorescence decay lifetimes of the compound.
elements.clean_text: Our analysis reveals that using a twisted luminescent molecular structure to increase the distance between molecules can effectively improve the QYs of compounds. The dipole stacking method of misaligned parallel molecules (J-aggregate) can improve the QY and increase the fluorescence decay lifetimes of the compound.

elements.content: The preliminary results of an empirical study are described. The structures of these compounds are distinct from one another. n-Pybim and all auxiliary aromatic carboxylic acid ligands display diverse combinations to coordinate with Zn/Cd­(II) ions and further extend the immobilization of complexes through hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions. They display different luminescence properties. The QYs of compounds 8 and 9 reaches 15.48% and 29.16%, and their decay lifetimes are 2.9 and 23.85 ns. In summary, this paper provides two methods to improve the efficiency of solid-state luminescence. (1) A twisted luminescent ligand is used to increase the distance between ligands to achieve high-efficiency luminescence. (2) Misaligned parallel molecular strong π–π stacking (J-aggregation) is used for high-efficiency illumination. These studies provide a potential strategy for synthesizing Zn/Cd­(II)–luminescence organic architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The preliminary results of an empirical study are described. The structures of these compounds are distinct from one another. n-Pybim and all auxiliary aromatic carboxylic acid ligands display diverse combinations to coordinate with Zn/Cd(II) ions and further extend the immobilization of complexes through hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions. They display different luminescence properties. The QYs of compounds 8 and 9 reaches 15.48% and 29.16%, and their decay lifetimes are 2.9 and 23.85 ns. In summary, this paper provides two methods to improve the efficiency of solid-state luminescence. (1) A twisted luminescent ligand is used to increase the distance between ligands to achieve high-efficiency luminescence. (2) Misaligned parallel molecular strong π-π stacking (J-aggregation) is used for high-efficiency illumination. These studies provide a potential strategy for synthesizing Zn/Cd(II)-luminescence organic architectures.

cln_elements.content: 0.2 mmol of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 2-pybim, H2ip acid, Na2CO3, and 15 mL of water were added to a Teflon tube. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred with a glass rod for about 5 min, reacted in a 160 °C oven for 4 days, and then cooled at ambient temperature. The yield of colorless crystals of compound 1 was 53%. Elemental analyses are displayed in Table S2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
{[Zn(2-pybim)(ip)] n ⋅H2O} n  (1)

0.2 mmol of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O, 2-pybim, H2ip acid, Na2CO3, and 15 mL of water were added to a Teflon tube. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred with a glass rod for about 5 min, reacted in a 160 °C oven for 4 days, and then cooled at ambient temperature. The yield of colorless crystals of compound 1 was 53%. Elemental analyses are displayed in Table S2.
